pull.title: Language fixups (release notes and #5533)
pull.body:
Includes the language clarification in #5533

Note this means a string change for the -help (I don't think RPC help is translated?)

events.body: ACK, but please either verify that Armory is actually incompatible, or just remove that mention.
A quick look on the forum (https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=903973.0) suggests that the next Armory release will be compatible with 0.10.0

events.message: en: Avoid ambiguous language regarding when transactions confirm

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -29,7 +29,8 @@ Downgrading warning
 
 Because release 0.10.0 makes use of headers-first synchronization and parallel
 block download, the block files and databases are not backwards-compatible
-with older versions of Bitcoin Core:
+with other software (notably the Armory wallet) nor older versions of Bitcoin
comments.body: Did anyone actually confirm that Armory isn't compatible with this?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -29,7 +29,8 @@ Downgrading warning
 
 Because release 0.10.0 makes use of headers-first synchronization and parallel
 block download, the block files and databases are not backwards-compatible
-with older versions of Bitcoin Core:
+with other software (notably the Armory wallet) nor older versions of Bitcoin
comments.body: I didn't, but I thought someone said they knew it wasn't... I guess it will be soon enough, so maybe we should leave out the parenthical region?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -41,7 +42,10 @@ stored on disk, which earlier versions won't support.
 
 If you want to be able to downgrade smoothly, make a backup of your entire data
 directory. Without this your node will need start syncing (or importing from
-bootstrap.dat) anew afterwards.
+bootstrap.dat) anew afterwards. It is possible that the data from a completely
+synchronised 0.10 node may be usable in older versions as-is, but this is not
+officially supported and may break as soon as the older version attempts to
comments.body: I would drop the "officially" -- it's not unofficially supported either. Just a possibility of working.
